[Content truncated]....pdf . The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) also previously released its own cybersecurity policy for IoT devices, delineating six strategic principles that it believes will help stakeholders stop unauthorized intruders from tampering with connected devices. See U.S. Dept. of Homeland Security, Strategic Principles for Securing the Internet of Things (IoT) ,Version 1.0 (Nov. 15, 2016), https://www.dhs.gov/securingtheIoT . NIST and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) developed a risk management framework for addressing cybersecurity issues. See NIST, Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity (2014), https://www.nist.gov/system/files/documents/cyberframework/cybersecurity-framework-021214.pdf . The Communications Security, Reliability, and Interoperability Council IV (CSRIC IV) developed a segment-specific analysis of the application of the Cybersecurity Framework, as well as recommendations for voluntary efforts to address cybersecurity concerns. See CSRIC IV, Working Group 4, Cybersecurity Risk Management and Best Practices, Final Report (2015), https://transition.fcc.gov/pshs/advisory/csric4/CSRIC_IV_WG4_Final_Report_031815.pdf . In addition, the Commission’s Technical Advisory Council issued its report on applying security to consumer IoT devices. See Federal Communications Commission Technical Advisory Council (FCC TAC), Cybersecurity Working Group, Technical Considerations White Paper (2015), https://transition.fcc.gov/oet/tac/tacdocs/reports/2015/FCC-TAC-Cyber-IoT-White-Paper-Rel1.1-2015.pdf ; see also Press Release, FTC, FTC Report on Internet of Things Urges Companies to Adopt Best Practices to Address Consumer Privacy and Security Risks (Jan. 27, 2015), https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2015/01/ftc-report-internet-things-urges-companies-adopt-best-practices-address-

this Order is widely informed by government actions to date and the significant work of industry and academia, we reiterate here background information also found in the IoT Labeling NPRM , and highlight more recent and ongoing efforts to address IoT security labeling across both private and public sectors. We previously noted the progress of international efforts with respect to IoT labeling, such as the publication of an assessment methodology for IoT security provisions to assist assessors of IoT products for Singapore’s Cybersecurity Label...[Content truncated]

Query1.title: Search warrant yields seizure of guns, marijuana
Query1.snippet: Apr 24, 2024 ... Guns, marijuana seized from Trotwood smoke shop ... TROTWOOD, Ohio (WDTN) — Police seized drugs and guns while serving a search warrant at Best ...

content.content:
WDTN.com
Please enter a search term.
Please enter a search term.

		by: Alex Pearson, Grace Hewitt 

			Posted: Apr 24, 2024 / 03:59 PM EDT 

			Updated: Apr 24, 2024 / 10:10 PM EDT 

		by: Alex Pearson, Grace Hewitt 

			Posted: Apr 24, 2024 / 03:59 PM EDT 

			Updated: Apr 24, 2024 / 10:10 PM EDT 
TROTWOOD, Ohio (WDTN) — Police seized drugs and guns while serving a search warrant at Best Buds Depot in Trotwood Wednesday morning.
Around 9 a.m. on April 24, police seized a large amount of marijuana along with 18 guns at the location on Salem Avenue. The owners are facing drug trafficking, possession of drugs and drug paraphernalia charges.
“I don’t care what law they pass. Drugs and guns is never a good combination,” said Trotwood Police Chief Erik Wilson.
According to the Secretary of State’s website, Goldwasser Smoke and Vape LLC filed the fictitious name Best Buds Depot on Jan. 20 of this year. Though now offline, their website advertised live resin carts and claimed to be the first in Ohio to sell legal THC products.
“If you go on the Division of Cannabis Control for the state of Ohio, who is the guest regulatory body for marijuana? They have this on their website. Currently, there are no individuals or entities licensed to sell non-medical cannabis in the state of Ohio and any sale of marijuana prior to non-medical licenses being issued may be subject to criminal penalties,” said Wilson.
...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This is the website for WDTN, a local news station in Ohio. Like WMAR, local news can provide useful information but may not uphold the same journalistic standards as national outlets. It is generally reliable, but local biases may impact the coverage.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article reports on a police seizure of guns and marijuana but does not involve Bill Maher or any discussions around smoking on television or FCC fines. It is unrelated.

Query1.snippet: Jun 24, 2022 ... 7 See id., at 843 (joint opinion of O'Connor, Kennedy, and Souter, JJ.). 8 Id., at 853. 9 Id., at 860. Page 12. 4. DOBBS v. JACKSON WOMEN'S ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]... legislature. 
Under this scheme, each trimester of pregnancy was reg -
ulated differently, but the most critical line was drawn at roughly the end of the second trimester, which, at the time, corresponded to the point at which a fetus was thought to achieve “viability,” i.e. , the ability to survive outside the womb. Although the Court acknowledged that States had a legitimate interest in protecting “potential life,” 1 it found that this interest could not justify any restriction on pre -
viability abortions. The Court did not explain the basis for this line, and even abortion supporters have found it hard to defend Roe ’s reasoning. One prominent constitutional scholar wrote that he “would vote for a statute very much like the one the Court end up drafting” if he were “a legislator,” but his assessment of Roe was memorable and brutal: Roe was “not constitutional law” at all and gave “al -
most no sense of an obligation to try to be.” 2
At the time of Roe , 30 States still prohibited abortion at all stages. In the years prior to that decision, about a third of the States had liberalized their laws, but Roe abruptly ended that political process. It imposed the same highly restrictive regime on the entire Nation, and it effectively struck down the abortion laws of every single State. 3 As         
> ——————
> 1Roe v. Wade , 410 U. S. 113, 163 (1973).
> 2J. Ely, The Wages of Crying Wolf: A Comment on Roe v. Wade , 82 Yale L. J. 920, 926, 947 (1973) (Ely) (emphasis deleted).
> 3L. Tribe, Foreword: Toward a Model of Roles in the Due Process of Life and Law, 87 Harv. L. Rev. 1, 2 (1973) (Tribe). 3Cite as: 597 U. S. ____ (2022)
> Opinion of the Court
Justice Byron White aptly put it in his dissent, the decision represented the “exercise of raw judicial power,” 410 U. S., at 222, and it sparked a national controversy that has em -
bittered our political culture for a half century. 4
Eventually, in Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pa. v. 
Casey , 505 U. S. 833 (1992), the Court revisited Roe , but the Members of the Court split three ways....[Content truncated]

Query2.title: Bill Maher Lights-Up On Network Television - NORML
Query2.snippet: Feb 16, 2016 ... It was, I presume, his way of demonstrating that smoking marijuana is no big deal, and does not cause the smoker to lose control or behave in an ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]... Laws Since 1970
*

*

\>\>Bill Maher Lights-Up On Network Television
Bill Maher Lights-Up On Network Television
==========================================
*   by 
*   Posted on 
Long-time marijuana legalization proponent, and NORML Advisory Board member, comedian Bill Maher, achieved some sort of milestone recently when he lit-up a joint during a humorous monologue on his HBO television show Real Time With Bill Maher.
Now, don’t get me wrong. There have likely been thousands of entertainers and celebrities over the years who have gotten stoned prior to appearing on a television program, and who have been comfortable performing in front of a national audience while stoned.
But this was different. Here was a celebrity talk-show host on a major network, who, in the middle of his monologue on the need to legalize marijuana nationwide, pulled a joint out of his jacket pocket, lit it and began toking. It was, I presume, his way of demonstrating that smoking marijuana is no big deal, and does not cause the smoker to lose control or behave in an inappropriate manner. Maher completed his monologue, which was extraordinarily funny, and continued with his program, without the slightest indication he was impaired by his smoking.
**Don’t Take Legalization for Granted**
Also, Maher clearly had a serious political purpose in mind when he decided to ignore the marijuana laws and light-up a joint on his show. He was using his monologue to remind his viewers that marijuana legalization does not occur without a lot of work from proponents in each individual state, and that none of us should presume the current political momentum will continue indefinitely. “Stop treating it like you could never lose it,” Maher warned.
That’s a message that resonates with those of us who lived through the 1970s, when, based on the report of the Marijuana Commission, we first decriminalized minor marijuana offenses in eleven states, and felt we were on the verge of winning nationwide. Instead, near the end of the decade the mood of the country turned far more conservative towards marijuana policy, with the rise of the parents’ movement and Nancy Reagan’s “Just Say No” campaign, and we saw our progress come to an abrupt halt. We failed to win another statewide marijuana reform measure for 18 years (until California legalized medical use in 1996).
There are important differences between those years and the current time, including an enormous increase in public support for legalization. In the 1970s, when we were winning decriminalization proposals at the state level, the Gallup Poll showed we enjoyed only about ...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML) focuses on lobbying for marijuana law reform. While it provides valuable information and advocacy for legalization efforts, it may exhibit bias towards pro-marijuana perspectives. It tends to provide factual information but is advocacy-oriented, so its reporting should be corroborated with other news sources for full context.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source discusses Maher lighting up a joint on his HBO show and suggests it was a political statement regarding marijuana legalization, which directly supports the claim about him smoking a joint during a broadcast. It does not discuss FCC fines, which lowers its score slightly.

Query2.title: Bill Maher Rejected Steve-O Interview Over Pot Smoking
Query2.snippet: May 17, 2024 ... I found it kind of upsetting when the Bill Maher podcast reached out and he smokes pot the whole time while he interviews people. I said I'd ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]... shoot the shit. This is an attempt to get conversation as real as it ever is. Just like if we were doing this, and I don’t see anything that we’ve said that I wouldn’t have just said to you if there were no cameras here — and you even know where the cameras are. Okay, so let’s remember that.”
“I have no feud with any of these ‘Jackass’ \,” Maher concluded. “I watched all the movies. They are funny.”
Maher is often seen smoking marijuana during his “Club Random” podcast interviews. Steve-O originally expressed shock that Maher would not forgo smoking weed for one interview, especially because Steve-O had appeared on other podcasts where the host was a marijuana enthusiast but agreed to respect his sobriety.
“I’m a clean and sober guy. It’s very important that I maintain my sobriety, it’s approaching 16 years,” Steve-O said on his own podcast at the time. “I am about to be sweet 16. Really, there’s nothing I value more than my sobriety. There’s nothing more that I protect than my recovery. I found it kind of upsetting when the Bill Maher podcast reached out and he smokes pot the whole time while he interviews people. I said I’d happily go on there, but while I’m on, out of respect for my sobriety, could he refrain from smoking pot. He said no and that’s a dealbreaker.”
As Steve-O’s story gained traction on social media platforms like X last month, some users pointed out that Maher had in fact respected his guest’s boundaries for marijuana in the past. During Sheryl Crow’s  Maher told her: “That’s when I need a joint … but I’d never light one up in front of you.” He refrained from smoking in front of her.
Maher’s full “Club Random” interview with Tony Hawk will be available on May 27.

Query2.title: High Times With Bill Maher: L.A.'s 'Inferiority Complex,' Wokeness ...
Query2.snippet: Mar 27, 2024 ... Our national nightmare is far from over, but for comedian Bill Maher, the culture war over Trump and wokeness is perfect fodder for 'Real ...

content.content:
Our national nightmare is far from over, but for the ‘Real Time’ host, it’s perfect fodder for the acerbic humor he delivers best — just don’t get him too stoned
*   
*   
*   
OUT OF RESPECT for both the reader and Bill Maher, I have cut every instance of the phrase “What was I saying?” from this article. Maher, who, in 2024, marks 22 years of hosting HBO’s _Real Time With Bill Maher,_ was very, very stoned for his _Los Angeles_ interview. And it wasn’t his fault. Someone working at the Woods — Woody Harrelson’s West Hollywood marijuana dispensary and consumption lounge that Maher and John McEnroe are minority owners in — handed him a Black Mamba, which was infused with both live resin and kief. Once she realized her mistake, she brought him a CBD tonic she claimed was an antidote. It was not.
We meet in one of the glass cabanas overlooking a koi pond and parrot cages in the jungle-themed Ganja Giggle Garden. It’s the same Treehouse cabana where Maher recently hung out with Paul McCartney, whom he says exceeded his high expectations by being neither full of himself nor guarded.
!
Bill Maher, s_tyled by Charlie Choukair,_ photographed at _The Woods Dispensary, which he co-owns with Woody Harrel...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Los Angeles Magazine (lamag.com) tends to cover local news and cultural stories, and it can be reliable for entertainment news. However, it is not a dedicated news organization, and the fact-checking process may not be as rigorous as mainstream media outlets. While it can provide context and information about events, it may not always adhere to the same standards of accuracy as more prominent news organizations.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article discusses Bill Maher and marijuana, highlighting his involvement with cannabis culture, but it doesn't directly address the specific incident of smoking a joint on his show or any FCC fines related to it. It mentions Maher being stoned during an interview but does not provide concrete connections to the live broadcast or fines.

QA.Question: Did Bill Maher smoke a joint on live broadcast, and were there FCC fines?
QA.Answer: Bill Maher did smoke a joint on live broadcast during his HBO show "Real Time with Bill Maher." This notable event occurred while he was discussing marijuana legalization, and he pulled out a joint, lit it, and began smoking in the middle of his monologue, effectively using it as a statement about the normalization of marijuana use and legalization efforts. As for FCC fines, there is no evidence or indication that the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) imposed any fines on Maher or his show as a result of this incident. While such actions could be possible in theory due to regulations on broadcasting content, the evidence does not show that Maher faced any legal repercussions for smoking during his show. This suggests that the act may have been tolerated within the context of the show's format and content regulations. Overall, the conclusion is: - Bill Maher smoked a joint on live broadcast: Yes. - Were there FCC fines: No evidence found.
